rev.comment: I think that is a bit of promotion to the imac (even if unintended!)

Line 1: Line 1:
{{pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes}}
{{pp-semi-vandalism|small=yes}}
â
[[Image:Yet another lolcat.jpg|thumb|right|A Lolcat image depicting a cat in an [[iMac]]]]
 
A '''lolcat''' is an image combining a [[photograph]], most frequently of a [[cat]], with a [[humour|humorous]] and [[Idiosyncrasy|idiosyncratic]] [[caption]] in (often) broken Englishâa dialect which is known as âlolspeak,â âkitteh,â or âkitty pidginâ and which parodies the poor grammar typically attributed to [[Internet slang]]. The name "lolcat" is a [[Compound (linguistics)|compound word]]<!-- note: not a portmanteau --> of the acronymic abbreviation "[[LOL]]" and the word "cat."<ref name="Silverman">{{cite web | author = Dwight Silverman | title = Web photo phenomenon centers on felines, poor spelling | publisher = [[Houston Chronicle]] | date = 2007-06-06 | url = http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/business/4862013.html | accessdate = 2008-09-21 }}</ref> A synonym for "lolcat" is ''cat macro'', since the images are a type of [[image macro]].<ref name="beacon">{{cite news
A '''lolcat''' is an image combining a [[photograph]], most frequently of a [[cat]], with a [[humour|humorous]] and [[Idiosyncrasy|idiosyncratic]] [[caption]] in (often) broken Englishâa dialect which is known as âlolspeak,â âkitteh,â or âkitty pidginâ and which parodies the poor grammar typically attributed to [[Internet slang]]. The name "lolcat" is a [[Compound (linguistics)|compound word]]<!-- note: not a portmanteau --> of the acronymic abbreviation "[[LOL]]" and the word "cat."<ref name="Silverman">{{cite web | author = Dwight Silverman | title = Web photo phenomenon centers on felines, poor spelling | publisher = [[Houston Chronicle]] | date = 2007-06-06 | url = http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/business/4862013.html | accessdate = 2008-09-21 }}</ref> A synonym for "lolcat" is ''cat macro'', since the images are a type of [[image macro]].<ref name="beacon">{{cite news
| url = <!--http://www.ohio.com/mld/beaconjournal/living/17346291.htm-->| title = Laugh at cat humor| author = Randy A. Salas| work = [[Akron Beacon Journal]], [[Star Tribune]]| date = 2007-06-09| accessdate = 2007-06-17| quote = At first, they were called cat macros, but now go mostly by the name lolcats.}}</ref> Lolcats are designed for [[photo sharing]] [[imageboard]]s and other internet forums. The term ''lolcat'' gained national media attention in the United States when it was covered by [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']],<ref name="Time">{{cite news|first=Lev |last=Grossman| url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1642897,00.html| title = Cashing in on Cute Cats| authorlink = Lev Grossman| date = 2007-07-12| accessdate 2007-07-12| work = [[Time Magazine]]}} Partial scan of the print edition: http://fcrunk.wellimean.com/memes/catstime.jpg</ref> which wrote that non-commercialized [[phenomenon|phenomena]] of the sort are increasingly rare, stating that lolcats have "a distinctly old-school, early 1990s, [[Usenet]] feel to [them]."
| url = <!--http://www.ohio.com/mld/beaconjournal/living/17346291.htm-->| title = Laugh at cat humor| author = Randy A. Salas| work = [[Akron Beacon Journal]], [[Star Tribune]]| date = 2007-06-09| accessdate = 2007-06-17| quote = At first, they were called cat macros, but now go mostly by the name lolcats.}}</ref> Lolcats are designed for [[photo sharing]] [[imageboard]]s and other internet forums. The term ''lolcat'' gained national media attention in the United States when it was covered by [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']],<ref name="Time">{{cite news|first=Lev |last=Grossman| url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1642897,00.html| title = Cashing in on Cute Cats| authorlink = Lev Grossman| date = 2007-07-12| accessdate 2007-07-12| work = [[Time Magazine]]}} Partial scan of the print edition: http://fcrunk.wellimean.com/memes/catstime.jpg</ref> which wrote that non-commercialized [[phenomenon|phenomena]] of the sort are increasingly rare, stating that lolcats have "a distinctly old-school, early 1990s, [[Usenet]] feel to [them]."
